data.title: UI is hard to use on 125% DPI monitor

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
It's not blurry or cut off like other issues I've seen here. It's just plain hard to click the menus and buttons.

I can set `"window.zoomLevel": 1.25` (100% + 20% * 1.25 = 125% :smile:) and that takes care of some of the issue, but it would be nice if it would automatically adjust so that I could leave `window.zoomLevel` at whatever zoom level I *really* want and have VS Code compensate for whatever monitor I happen to be using. For example, I'll sometimes remote in from a computer with 100% DPI and sometimes from a computer with 200% DPI. Every application that I use adjusts except VS Code.

One other thing- the menu bar does not resize, and the menu item text is almost falling off the bottom edge of the menu bar. It's pretty thin to click on.

- VSCode Version: 1.9.0 27240e71ef390bf2d66307e677c2a333cebf75af
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

data.title: Snippets stopped working
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.0 (27240e71ef390bf2d66307e677c2a333cebf75af, 2017-02-02T08:31:00.827Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.10586
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|code-beautifier|michelemelluso|1.6.2|
|vscode-scss|mrmlnc|0.6.0|
|vscode-sql-beautify|sensourceinc|0.0.4|
|lorem-ipsum|Tyriar|1.0.0|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use VS Code <1.9.
2. Add a snippet. See example of my snippet below.
3. Upgrade to 1.9
4. Insert snippet command reports "There are no entries to pick from"
5. Intellisense does not list known snippets.

My snippet (installed in both JavaScript and JavaScript React):

    {
        "JSX Comment":{ 
            "prefix":"jc",
            "body":[
                "{/* $1 */}$0"
            ],
        "description": "Inserts a React-style comment"
    }
}

Note: I tried re-adding a snippet after the upgrade, and newly added snippets do not appear either. It seems as though VS Code fails to load snippets for the current file type.

data.body:
vscode: 1.9.0

From discussion: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/18963

data.title: [Markdown Syntax] Splitting lines causes formatting to not work
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a markdown file with the following text:
  ```markdown
  **_NOTE_: Broken highlighting
  when a line break introduced.**
  ```

## Expected Output:

All the text within the `**` is marked as bold.

## Actual Output:

Only the text within `_` is italicised but the bold style between `**` is not applied.

## NOTE: This renders correctly as expected in the preview. It's just the editor syntax that's broken.

![capture](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10473142/22623036/13bb6d40-eb73-11e6-84b7-15fdc59e73de.PNG)

data.title: Emmet Tab Key Not Expanding In Certain Scenario
data.body:
After doing a particular sequence of actions, the Tab key for Emmet is not expanding the html shortcut. It instead jumps to the title element.

If I then close the file and re-open it, the Tab key does work.

after creating a new file, using the "!" shortcut to create an html skeleton, and then trying to expand an html shortcut.


- VSCode Version: Version 1.9.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04.1 LTS

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new file
2. Type ! followed by Tab for the html skeleton shortcut
3. Type an html shortcut in the body, for example div#one{RELATIVE}
4. Press Tab
5. The cursor goes to the Title element instead of expanding the shortcut

data.title: Ionide Send to F# Interactive terminal window produces garbage output in vscode 1.9.0
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->
Something broke when updating to 1.9.0. I don't know if you or Ionide folks need to fix this.

- VSCode Version: 1.9.0
- OS Version: OSX El capitan 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install Ionide-fsharp extension
2. Send any fsharp code line to Interactive window with option + /
3. you get garbage chars at the terminal prompt after command executes
3. Next time you send your command will fail due to the garbage chars

From terminal - F# interactive  
```
> type PersonType = {First:string; Last:string}
- ;;

type PersonType =
  {First: string;
   Last: string;}

> ^?^? <-- Garbage chars
```

data.title: Delay when saving files in projects with tasks.json

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.0
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create new directory for a minimal test project.
```sh
mkdir test
cd test
mkdir .vscode
echo // Empty File > .vscode/tasks.json
echo Test > test.txt
```

2. Open minimal test project
```
code --disable-extensions . 
```

3. Edit `test.txt` file (e.g., add a blank line) and save changes (File > Save)

Expected: File to immediately save as it did with 1.8.1 (and verified after downgrading to 1.8.1)

Actual: File saves but with approximate 1 second delay.

Workarounds:
* Remove the `tasks.json`
* Revert to [1.8.1](https://vscode-update.azurewebsites.net/1.8.1/darwin/stable)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use¬†jQuery for intellisense in an HTML document.
2. Use jQuery for intellisense in a JS document.

Hello. I'm trying to use JQuery in a separate¬†JS file so that my html pages aren't too convoluted but looks like JQuery intellisense only works in HTML files and not in JS files. Am I wrong? Can I request that intellisense works in JS files as well as HTML files?

data.title: Quick Open should populate search field with selected text
data.body: When launching Quick Open, if there is text selected in the editor, populate the search field with the selected text.

data.title: Go to definition should also find functions across plain JS project
data.body:
Currently 'go to definition' seems to only work for some symbols within the same file.  I work on a very large project with custom built module system.  Navigating the code base currently best works with Brackets and WebStorm.
Both Brackets and WebStorm can find the function definition of any function for any type of JS project.
If there are multiple possible definitions for a function, they will present a list from which you can choose.

data.title: Mocha timeouts do not work when using inbuilt Mocha configuration for launch.json
Find in all files should allow search within results

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: Find in all files should have the ability to do a search again within the files which were found from a previous search.

data.title: Find in all files should sort by priority
data.body:
Find in all files should sort using the following priority by default:

1. Results in current active file
2. Results in opened files 
3. Results in recent files
4. All other files

Brackets all file search for example does a sorting similar to the above which is very useful.

There should be a button to also do an alphabetical sort.

- Node.js 6.5.0

1. Place a breakpoint on a function call (local to module or within project scope doesn't seem to matter)
2. Press Step Into (F11) or click Step Into in the UI

Expected: Step into the method.
Results: Steps over (as if F10 was pressed)

data.title: Extensions: Include and release additional (resource) files with a project
data.body:
I would like to develop an extension that runs a [NodeJS server](https://nodejs.org/api/http.html#http_http_createserver_requestlistener), written in [TypeScript](https://www.typescriptlang.org/).

I would like to include other things as my generated `.js` files, like `.css`, fonts or images, that should be released with my extension into `/out/src` folder.

The only workarround I know, is to include these files as Base64 encoded data in TypeScript files:

```typescript
// resources.ts

export RESOURCES = {
    'my-css-file.css': 'LyogVmlzdWFsIFN0dWRpbyBDb2RlIHJvY2tzISAqLw0KDQpib2R5IHsNCiAgICAvKiBhd2Vzb21lICovDQp9DQoNCmhlYWQgew0KICAgIC8qIGJyaWxsYW50ICovDQp9'
}
```

I don't think that this is a good solution. Libraries like [FontAwesome](http://fontawesome.io/) or [Bootstrap](https://getbootstrap.com/) will increase the code extremly.

Is there a way to setup things like the `package.json` file to link to external files that should also be released with the extension?

data.title: Clearing Terminal only clears visible area
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9
- OS Version: Windows 10 Build 14986

Default terminal is powershell

Steps to Reproduce:

1. In VSCode generate enough output to cause terminal to scroll
2. Type `cls`

Expected:

Entire terminal should be cleared, including content outside of viewport (if scroll up). This is how it works in a powershell console.

Actual:

Only the visible area is cleared. By scrolling up old content is visible.


My use-case:

I like to `cls` and then run `npm test`. Then the beginning of my terminal is where my test output starts.

Now I `cls`, but I have no idea where the beginning of my test output is.

data.title: [proposal] Ability to export all installed extensions & share that with other PCs to install
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: **1.9**
- OS Version: **Any**

> The idea is simple but I was digging around to see if it was available anywhere without any luck.

It'd be great to be able to select some **"Export All Installed Extensions"**, maybe somewhere here in the menu options for extensions.

This would be great, so that you could easily **share** those 20+ favorite extensions you have with friends, or even all the laptops/PCs you might have with VSCode installed, *and get up to speed in seconds*. 

Maybe even an IT solution that is pre-installing VSCode on new machines and wants them all to have the same baseline extensions.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2574412/22619267/2967c12a-eabf-11e6-8749-acfc59f96ae7.png)

^ Maybe somewhere here in this menu?

---

Anyway just an idea, ‚ù§Ô∏è  VSCode, just thought I'd get the idea out there, see if others would be interested in it as well!

data.title: VSCode error message: 'Cannot find name 'Promise'.' with "additionalFlags": es2015.promise"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.0 (27240e71ef390bf2d66307e677c2a333cebf75af, 2017-02-02T08:23:30.856Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.3.0
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|beautify|HookyQR|0.7.3|
|jshint|dbaeumer|0.10.15|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.2|
|tslint|eg2|0.8.1|
|hopscotch|idleberg|0.1.4|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|2.5.1|
|vim|vscodevim|0.5.2|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Typescript project with `tsconfig.json`:
```JSON
{
    "compilerOptions": {
            "allowJs": true,
            "pretty": true,
            "target": "es5",
            "declaration": false,
            "removeComments": false,
            "inlineSources": true,
            "inlineSourceMap": true,
            "sourceMap": false,
            "experimentalDecorators": true,
            "fast": "never", 
            "additionalFlags": "--lib dom,es5,es2015.promise,es2015.collection,es2015.iterable",
            "verbose": true
    }
}
```
2. VSCode configured to use workspace typescript version:
```
    // User the typescript compiler that is used for build client flow
    "typescript.tsdk": "config/node_modules/typescript/lib",
```
3. However VSCode `Problems` window shows Promise errors-
````
file: 'file:///xxx.ts'
severity: 'Error'
message: 'Cannot find name 'Promise'.'
at: '70,36'
source: 'ts'
```
Even though we have promise support added in `additionalFlags` in `tsconfig.json`.
